div1.p: Barber discusses the failure of the algae chara to prevent larval breeding and desires a copy of a report that Carter suggested would be useful to his work.

div1.head: Letter from M. A. Barber to Henry Rose Carter, September 20, 1923
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Crowley, La. Sept. 20, 1923.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Here I am neglecting to write you a letter of sympathy
for your illness until I want some information from you! But I think
you will be more interested in the subject that in any sort of
commiseration. But I am heartily glad to hear that you are on the road to
recovery and maybe on the road to Washington too.

It is Chara again. This summer I have had an excellent opportunity
of seeing the not-working of this antilarval agent. Rice plots in the
rice Expt. Sta. here full of it all arranged for study. Of the species I am not
yet informed. I have sent specimens to Dr. Robinson, the Chara authority, and
also to the Bureau of Plant Industry, but no answer yet.

Larvae all stages over abundant Chara as elsewhere, even thicker
where matted Chara protects against fish. Also breeding over Nitella
another member of the same group of algae.

I did a lot of laboratory experiments to try to determine if
this Chara could be effective there as Caballero states. In a cup with
abundant Chara quad. will develop from egg to imago in 12 days, counting
from the night of oviposition, and not very good weather for quadding either.
Part of Chara rots and part remains living as shown by rotation of protoplasm
in cells. Many cultures in several sorts of containers. Sometimes larvae
die in Chara, but same happens with some Spirogyra cultures. Main thing
is to have plenty of food. I should like to know what results Caballero
would get in his “crystalladores” if he floated a cork on the surface of the
water and put a little rotten Chara or Spirogyra on it. Sometimes scums
interfere, but doubtful if more often with Chara than with any other alga.
Dried and powdered Chara a fair food, crushed green Chara a good food() or
source of food, for other organisms come it to supplement) and crushed
spores of Chara also nourishing, or at least not poisonous.

I thought it worth while to get out a short paper, although
the dog may be dead anyway. I am trying to get together the literature
and applied to the Hyg. Laboratory. They kindly sent me photostats of
Caballero's originals and I have Vasconcelos' aticle, but the Hyg. Library
could not get me the things I wished much, the Report Proc. Antimal.
Advisory Comm. Palestine, 6th Meeting, the reference you so kindly gave me.
There is a copy in the Surg. Gen. Library, but Mr. M otter wrote me that
this copy would not be ready for distribution until next fall or winter.
Now do you know where I could get the loan of some other copy? I will
cross my heart and promise to return it within a week or less.

All going well here. We are trying to get at the amount of malaria in
this rice country. Plenty of Anopheles, but it is remarkable how much
thicker they are about Stuttgart. Dr. Fricks visited region around Stuttugart
this month so that we could get a comparison during the same time.
div1.closer: With best wishes, M.A. Barber M.A.Barber.
